Comments_List: How to get started on analyzing data when someone from a completely different field comes in. How to ask the important questions, do some data visualization, how to communicate with non-statistics people, how to understand quickly someone's else problem.
I learned a lot about how real consulting may go in the real world. I saw how many times a main issue is just data cleaning and making sure your data actually is what you think it is.
The data analysis workflow which is very useful for statistical practical work. We also learned many programming techniques in R.

This class should have had more guests this year. But on the days we had guests, it was very interesting to try to understand the data, ask questions, do some visualization, and try to answer some problems. I really like the class being in an informal way, being in a small class, and getting to know better the people from the department in it.
The class could be improved by having more guests as a lot of times we didn't have a guest to work with.

It showed us how data analysis is done, especially for real world problems, with actual researchers or professionals with data problems they need to solve. That made the course very interesting and relevant.

I would not recommend this class to non-statistics people. I'd recommend this course to students interested in seeing cases, with many di erent datasets and how to ask questions to get to the point quickly and see what's important in the data.
I would recommend it because I did enjoy it a lot.
Yes, if they would to experience how data analysis is done for actual problems that practitioners face.
